Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2009 09:40PM hope4cure wrote: Questions ~ OK.  Does anyone else here have issues with lying flat or semi flat?  I haven't been able to sleep in my regular bed since the surgery.  The recliner is the most comfortable place I have found so far.  I noticed that when I lie flat or close to flat, the expanders feel like 2 ton rocks on top of me.   Ouch!    Later, when I tried to sit up the pain is very bad in the underarm/side area.  It just takes my breath away.  Also, my pain has really improved since the drains were removed but it keeps going and going and going.  I am pretty concerned that this will last until the expanders come out.   ~Sigh~  and that is at least 6 months from now.    Any good tips on pain relief?   I am taking the prescribed meds but they only do so much.  The pain NEVER lets up.   It has become more like "background noise" instead of a heavy metal rock band screaming in my ear.   Can you relate?
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2009 09:13PM hope4cure wrote: mooma - Now, can you pass along the name of this procedure?   I am really interested.   The PS I have did not offer that to me.   I also didn't have enough tummy for a flap but I do have some fat there and I am feeling pretty flat and empty on top!    Got to ask you a question -  do you have a really wierd feeling when you drink something cold?   When I drink something cold - it is like I feel it going down and I have funny sensation in my chest.   I think it is because there is no fat there anymore.

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2009 06:54AM hope4cure wrote: Hi all, Bee- thanks for asking about me.  I am checking out a new PS on August 10th.  That is the earliest I can get in.   It feels like an eternity.   I should have been done already.   Anyway, I am considering writing out my thoughts before I go in a letter since I wanted to be up-front regarding my expectations from my doctor.   I am not a difficult patient but I do expect a doctor to be a good listener, willing to answer my questions, respectful, kind and a little humor wouldn't hurt either.   I thought with the letter they will understand where I am coming from.  If they don't understand or cannot connect with me then I will continue looking.   The down side to any more delay would be the concern over my work situation.   I honestly do not know how much longer I might have my job.   If there are a lot of funding cuts to my agency, I might be laid off.   I believe I will be able to use COBRA and keep the insurance.  Although, I would feel so much better to just have it all done.  Mooma - sorry to hear about your burn.  Ouch! Terri - great news on your results!   I was relieved to get my results back after the surgery.   They said the same thing - which was a huge relief.  Wish me luck gang!   I hope I love this doctor and we will be able to schedule and do the exchange surgery soon. Thanks! Jennifer

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2009 09:03PM hope4cure wrote: I am reading all the posts of ones who had the MX the same day as me 2/23 and already having fills.   My first one is next Tuesday.  The PS told me 4 weeks from the date of surgery.   Interesting.    I am looking forward to it but a little scared too.   I hope it doesn't hurt.   I have had my share of that already. my560sel -  There is nothing wrong with taking Xanax.  There are lots of people who do and dealing with all of this stuff - we have good reason for the drug.  Also, if you do seek out counsel from your Hope and Cope Dept, I hope it is better than the one I had at my hospital.  They didn't return calls, refused to speak to me over the phone (wanted to be person only) and told me they would visit me in my hospital room the day after the surgery.  (They were a no-show.)  So, guess what is going on my review when I get one from the hospital about my stay?    Perhaps they had some bigger fish to fry but don't tell me one thing and not follow through.   This world of BC is crazy enough.   Honestly, I have found more answers, more hope and encouragement from this discussion board than any other place.    These ladies KNOW what you are going through and can RELATE to your pain and suffering.  I am glad I found it. ~ Jennifer
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2009 02:52PM hope4cure wrote: 2new1s - Hi.  Thanks for the pep talk.  I don't think I have too many negative feelings.  I know I have some.  I know I feel tired all the time.  I do sleep even though I don't have Xanax.   I sleep in the recliner.   I think the pain meds make me pretty drowsy.  I try to take Advils through the day and then the stronger stuff before I go to bed in the recliner.    I was always on the go before BC.   Talking to all of you helps inspire me to not give in or give up.   I am looking forward to the day I will be on the go and peppy again.  Bee - I was told by my PS to not raise my arms too high up above my head because that could result in the expanders flipping.   She told me I could wash my hair but not raise my arms higher than that.  After I was told this - I have been really cautious not to do it.   That would freak me out.   Sounds like you are taking it pretty well.   Don't give up on your fight with the insurance.   I scrutinize my insurance statements and found something that didn't look right on it.   It showed I owed the anesthesiologist at the hospital that was covered under PPO.  I questioned it and they adjusted it.  It saved me $1300.00.   That was one phone call worth making for sure.  I cannot see how they can refuse to cover your situation.   Keep fighting it.    By the way, what state are you from?  Some state laws are better than others. FYI:  If you want to know where we are heading in the realm of health care.  Please read the article titled:  Ruin Your Health With the Obama Stimulus Plan: Betsy McCaughey .   This article  can be found on Bloomberrg.com   It is very sobering and scary.   When you are facing BC - you don't want to exclude anything that might help your situation - I know I don't.   Plus, I don't want anyone else dictating to my doctor what kind of care I can receive.   I want to have that choice.  Take care everyone!
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2009 09:40PM hope4cure wrote: Hey Bee - It is so cool to find someone that travels in some of the same circles.   Yes.  I think I have been to that town.   I have gone to Brown County, Indiana in October.   And OH MY GOODNESS is it ever beautiful!!    The trees in full Fall color will take your breath away.   I have been to some type of festival.  But it has been so many years ago, I cannot remember the name of it.  I was pregnant with my daughter at the time and I didn't think to call ahead to book a room and everything was booked solid.   Finally, a very kind hotel person arranged somehow to get us a room.  I was so grateful.  I was like 7 1/2 months along and very tired on my feet.   I would have hated to sleep in the vehicle like that all night.   I think they took pity on me.  If I ever go again, I will definitely book a room way in advance.   Apparently, a lot of other people loved the trees and the festivals too. I went to my local town again today (5 mile drive).  It was one of the few times I have driven myself.  I found a pretty cool bra in Freds which is a bargain type store like Dollar General.  It was a tube bra with a little paddiing.  It is working great and I can take it off really easily too.  Very cheap at $4.99.  I have found where the straps attach into the bra somehow irritate my underarm area and cause me more pain.  With this tube bra it is much more comfortable.  Sometimes the little stores like Freds have more than you think.  I think it is like they buy wholesale lots or something.   I have found Disney stuff there before.   I still haven't made it to Target yet.  2new1s - Sounds like you are really improving and moving forward.  Anyone notice ever so slight "shifting" of the expanders?   I notice it when I first get up out of my recliner in the AM.   It seems like they had shifted a little during the night and then adjust back during the day.   I think gravity and how you sleep affects them.   Do you agree?   I wonder if this is how the final implant will act too.  Hmmmm.

My next appointment is June 30th.  With the cuts in Illinois, I may be out of job after the 30th.  ??    I wish the legislators will pass a budget that works for people.  More people out of a job will not help the situation but only worsen it.   Regardless, I need to keep the insurance through the rest of my BC ordeal.    Keep your fingers crossed!

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2009 02:45PM hope4cure wrote: dani42 -  You are smaller than I.  I think my ribcage is like 30 or 31 inches.   I am taller and heavier too.   Although, I am not overweight.   I could lose about 10 lbs.  It sounds like not all things are being communicated from your PS.  Sometimes I think they believe they just know best and leave us out of the equation even though we are ones that have to live with it from here on.   I feel like not everything is being communicated to me either.  I was told yesterday that I didn't need to do any more fills.   The PS said that she didn't think my skin would tolerate any more.  However, it doesn't look like it is having issues to me.  I believe I am at 470 ccs right now.   They did the "overfill" yesterday when I was in the office.   I am close to my old size but don't really want to lose any of the amount/size I have right now which I believe will happen at the next surgery.  So, I am wondering if I should go for a 2nd option too.   Plus, I tried to communicate my situation with work/insurance yesterday and she didn't seem all that concerned.  She just said  "that is unfortunate" and that was all she said.  It was like "Oh well, not my problem"  She always seemed a little too "clinical" and not as "personable" to me. Anyway, maybe I am just frustrated with everything right now.   Are you going for silicone?  I read the material on them and it sounds like they are blamed for a lot of ailments.  Most are not substantiated but others are "well perhaps".  So, I am still considering what to do for sure.  Any suggestions?

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2009 07:28PM hope4cure wrote: dani42 - How long would your surgery be postponed?   If you are pleased with the 2nd one, I would be tempted to go with them.   It is a hard decision.  How did you go about finding a 2nd PS?   Maybe tell the 1st one what the 2nd one told you and see if works?   Good luck with your decision.  Bee54-  Good luck with your surgery. EternalOptimism - I have no nipples but do have some sensation on one side.  Most of the sensation is gone which is probably a good thing when dealing with tissue expanders.  They can be painful.   When I go for fills I feel the prick of needle on one side every time and no feeling on the other side.   I was told everyone is different.

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 07:31PM hope4cure wrote: suegmomof3 - I had bilateral on 2/23 and was able to get 2 of my 4 drains out this past week.   They said all the pain I had been experiencing was normal and the redness around the drains were normal too.   They had told me to swab antibiotic ointment on it when I changed the dressing.  I believe as long as you are not developing an infection - you will be OK.   If it looks like puss or something like that - I would definitely call them right away.    The drains have been extremely painful to me and just getting the 2 removed made a huge difference.   They are killers!   I understand your pain - it is really really bad.   When I saw the PS and told her all the pain - every pain under the sun including the burning, stabbing pain I had been experiencing was "normal".   I also have been living on pain killers - better now than before.  I was taking the max dose and "wishing" for more but also down to like 1 pain killer every 4 hours instead of 2 at a time.    Hang in there!   I totally understand where you are coming from!
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2009 08:13PM hope4cure wrote: Dani42 -  2 weeks post op seems way too early to return to work.  You know your body better than anyone else.   Don't hesitate to be your own best advocate!     My doctor told me the typical time for healing is 4-6 weeks.   At this point in time - I am at the 2 week point myself (Feb 23 was my surgery date), I would not be in any shape to return to work unless it was like 1-2 hours a day tops.   If I were you, I would be getting a note from your surgeon to your boss for more time off.   If you over do it - it could slow down the healing process.  I think as women we try and push ourselves too much!   This is YOUR time to heal and rest.   Don't rob yourself of it.   Your body just went through a major change and if your boss doesn't understand then they are being a "jerk" and should trade places with you for a day or two and then see what they think.
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2009 09:31PM hope4cure wrote: Ladies ~ Not passing judgment here ~ if that was my husband ~ I would be very disappointed in him.   I know men an be "jerks" at times but they need to be there in the serious times when you really need them.  I have been married for 19 years this year and my husband was there for both my lumpectomy and bilateral MX.   He was so great in the hospital that the nurses asked him if he had a job because they wanted to hire him.  No joke!    Now, that is not to say that he hasn't done some really dopey things from time to time.   It would just be very disappointing to me if he wasn't there for the "big" things.    My heart goes out to you gals!   That should not be!    If the tables were turned ~ wouldn't they want and expect you to be there for them?  I have heard stories from some of my other friends about their DH and how they "deal" with their spouse's diagnosis and some really do put their heads in the sand.   Ugh.

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2009 08:35AM hope4cure wrote: Well they said 6 months but I would gladly opt for less.   Maybe that is the general thing they say to people (to not get their hopes up) and then they might finish up earlier?   I was a 38C before all this transpired and that is pretty close to where I want to end up.   Maybe that also is factoring in to what they are telling me.   Six months seems like an eternity right now.

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2009 06:48PM hope4cure wrote: jpixstix - ABDs are pads for draining wounds.  They might even go by another name.  I don't know what the ABD stands for.  Even though my "wounds" were not really "draining" for very long, I continued to use them and I am still using them.  I had a home health nurse come for awhile after my surgery and she brought me some too.   You can get them in different sizes like 5 X 9 and larger.  They are pretty soft and comfortable to wear and don't rub or grate against the skin.   I think it was one reason why my incision healed up so fast.   I replaced them daily which also helped keep the area extra clean and probably kept away any chance of infection too.   I would gently wash the area with the soap provided from the hospital, put on the prescribed cream on the incision and drain holes then I would put the ABD pads over the area and then the bra.   It made it more comfortable.  When the drain holes were draining a little, it helped to keep those spots cleaner and less irritated too.  You can buy these at any pharmacy and even Wal-Mart in the bandaid section.  You can get a box at a time.  They can get a little pricey over time.   I think a box of 12 costed around $5.  The home health nurse said I could also use sanitary pads too.  I tried that but - they didn't quite work well on that part of the body.  HAHAHAHA!!!!    I went back to the ABDs.  I think I am healed up now where I can graduate to something else like a comfortable sports bra ( if there is such a thing) but thought I would ask my PS opinion first.   Hope this helps.   ~ Jennifer
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2009 09:55AM hope4cure wrote: I am here too.  Sorry, I have just been lazy lately.  I haven't wanted to do anything much.   I went for my first fill on Tuesday.   It went pretty well that day.  Wednesday, however, I was hurting most of the day.   I had to take more pain meds.   Since then, I have just wanted to rest.  I don't have any motivation right now.   Not sue what is up with me.   I just feel tired of it all.   I know I am past the worst of it but still have weeks to go.   I am tired of hurting all the time and limited in my ability to do much. ~ Jennifer

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2009 08:03PM hope4cure wrote: Just to add to the discussion - after my mastectomy they found what was called "Atypical Lobular Hyperplasia" which is a lesion that did not show up on any mammograms nor the MRI.   The surgeon told me that it was not cancer nor pre-cancer but a precursor.   I researched it more when I came home and from what I found out - it could have eventually turned into LCIS.   So, that was confirmation enough for me that I chose the right course in choosing the mastectomy.  I too had to reassure countless family members and friends that I believed I was doing the right thing.   I had already had a lumpectomy back in Oct 08.   Further testing could not tell for sure if there was anything else.   The doctors gave me options and I chose this one.  The way I looked at it - yes it is pretty radical but so is cancer.   If it comes back - it generally comes back with a vengence.   I have a young child that I want to be sure to raise and see her children.   I chose to be a little radical myself and I haven't regretted it.    You do what YOU feel is the right thing to do.  Research it all out and make the informed choice.    Best of luck and peace to you!
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2009 04:14AM hope4cure wrote: Hi all I have definitely decided to change my PS.  I came to the conclusion this doctor just doesn't care about me.   I gave them the benefit of the doubt and worked with them long enough.  It just isn't working out.   "Icy" is a good word to describe them.   It is a long story but over and over they have demonstrated a disregard for me.   So, I am on the search for a new one.  The surgeon that did my original MX is helping me.   I really liked this doctor.  She was excellent.  I so hope I find a really good PS and then get a date for the surgery set up.   Although, I know it is not a good idea to switch doctors midway.  Frustrating. I am so stressed out right now.  I have even stopped my monthly cycle.   I am 40 and not ready for menopause.  The OB/GYN said it could be just temporary but makes me worry more.  Plus, I still am holding out hope that someday I could have another child.   We were trying for our 2nd when I got my diagnosis last year.   I feel like my chances are steadily dwindling away.   My DH hints at adoption but I am just not there yet.  Bee - The bras you suggested are the same ones I have found.  They work great for me too.

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2009 02:21PM hope4cure wrote: dani42 - Glad you are doing so well.  I have 4 drains, 2 of them should come out this coming Tuesday and the final 2 next week.  They are causing me the most pain followed by the expanders.   I was a 38C - so I don't know if the amount they have to take off makes a bigger difference?   Anyway, I decided this hurts more than child birth for sure.  That extreme pain only lasted like 5-7 hours and this keeps going and going.   I am hoping the drains don't hurt removing them.   I will definitely take a pain med before I go.
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2009 01:44PM hope4cure wrote: Dianne  - I beginning to think the same thing.   I am hopeful that after I get the final 2 drains out tomorrow - I will feel better.   I have been such extreme pain.  The drains feel like hot knives in my sides.   The expanders - well it hurts to breathe deeply, cough and especially to laugh.  I watched a comedy movie the other day and had to take a pain pill afterwards because I caused myself to hurt worse from all the laughing.   I keep thinking ahead and saying to myself.  "No pain no gain" and when the weather gets nicer,  I will be feeling and looking better.   Take it easy!    ~ Jennifer
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 04:31PM hope4cure wrote: For those who reported being itchy, I was itchy too but they told me to take some Benadryl which worked well and took care of it.   I am using hydrocodone too which for the most part makes me drowsy.  I did, however, had a strange sensation this morning.   I woke up and feel like I was having chills.   I had a tingly sensation start around where my drains were and then it traveled down my body and felt sort of like a chill but it was tingly and then it traveled up and then down my arms.  I felt cold afterwards and covered up more and I kept having these "chills" over and over.   I took my temp to make sure I wasn't developing a fever and it was normal.   The "chills" eventually stopped and I wondered if it was like a nerve issue.   Anyone else experiencing these tingly "chills"?  As far as my pain, it is better now that those (ball and chains) - drains came out.   They came out yesterday.  WHOO HOO!!!  I told the doctor that they were going to come out one way or another.  (I seriously was planning to remove them if they didn't do it.)   Fortunately they agreed it was time for them to come out.   It was a really wierd feeling.   One of the drains was wrapped up by my sternum and it felt really creepy coming down and across my chest.  ICK!!!    I am really sore but not hurting quite as bad.  The surgeon was pleased to see the incisions healing up so well.   She gave me a printout of my final path report and went over it with me.  The report was excellent and I just broke down crying in relief.   It is gone, gone, gone!!!!!.  No lymph nodes involved, etc.  I didn't need any further treatment or icky drugs.  I just need to heal now.    I got what I was praying for.  Thank you GOD!!! The interesting thing about the path report.....the right breast was the one with the DCIS and in that same breast they found something else that they called Atypical Lobular Hyperplasia.  She explained it as not cancer, not pre-cancer but something that could have potentially developed into cancer down the road.  So, I feel that I definitely made the right decision to have chosen the bilateral mastectomy.  I just want to be free of it and some may have viewed my route as being overkill but not I - I don't trust this stuff!!!   I will go the extra mile to rid myself of it.    I researched it more when I came home and found out that Atypical Lobular Hyperplasia can turn into ILCS or ILC.   It just floors me.  Cancer is so scary and you have no idea you have this inside you.   I don't know if I have a heightened awareness of cancer now or what but I think it is entirely too commonplace.   Too many people are coming up with it. Did you all see the story of the 7 year old girl who doctors took out six of her organs to remove a cancerous tumor?   She went home from the hospital yesterday and is doing great.   Stories like this one really gives you admiration for this little person.  I have a 7 year old daughter and I could not imagine going through that - that poor family.  The little girl was amazing - so beautiful, sweet and optimistic.   I hope she has a long and happy life. Take care everyone and sorry for the long post.
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2009 02:51PM hope4cure wrote: jillisucat - Yeah, it is amazing how one day, one phone call can change things.   I was going along my merry way thinking everything was great (never had much more than a common cold) and BAM!!   You get knocked off your feet with the news.   WHAT!??   Are you kidding me?!!   It is hard to believe.  Then comes the whirlwind of doctors, nurses, tests, reports and you are asking "When can I get off this ride?"   "I don't want to be on it anymore!"   "How did I get here?!!"   "Am I going to wake up and this is going to just be a bad dream?!!"  I wish it was just a bad dream.  It is amazing.   I am glad to have found a place where breast cancer patients/survivors can come together and give each other support.   It is not good to be alone going through it.  Sharing experiences, words of encouragment and hope is so important.   I hope that I will live to see a cure to this someday.    Then all of us BC sisters can have the biggest celebration party ever! Thanks for sharing your experience.  I have the implants now.  They are definitely uncomfortable and I know it will be a long 6 months.

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2009 02:59PM hope4cure wrote: 2new1s Sorry to hear of your infection!    Sounds like you have really been through it!   I wonder if having an infection makes the drains hurt more to remove.  I had a friend who developed an infection with hers and had to be in the hospital for like 11 days.   When they pulled her drains she said it was terribly painful.    Keep a close eye on things.   Good luck to you and wishing you a quick recovery.
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2009 07:51PM hope4cure wrote: Hi all, Thanks for the information on the bras.  I will have to check out Target sometime.  I had my first fill today and it went really well.  The PS was extremely pleased with my incision healing and so that made me really happy.    She said I could move on to a different bra if I liked as long as it wasn't underwire and wasn't too tight.  I actually have had some feeling come back in my breasts and did feel the prick of the needle on one side.   It hurt a little but not that bad.  I didn't feel anything on the left side.  It was definitely interesting.   Glad I have one done.  Not exactly sure how many more to go.  She also told me that 3 months out from the surgery is usually a time when people really start to feel like their old self again.  I am looking forward to that - 2 months to go! ~ Jennifer
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2009 09:09PM hope4cure wrote: Hi all, I haven't posted in awhile since I have been back to work and seeming to not find much free time now.   I have read your posts and I am thinking to myself I am really behind all of you on the fills.  Wow.   I go every other week.  Are you going weekly?    I really don't believe I am up to the #;s you are posting.  Terri - Great news on the clean path report.  Isn't amazing the difference you will find in doctors?  Some are wonderful and others are total jerks.  Go with the ones who will be respectful of your questions and care enough to take the time to give you answers.   After all, that is their job and what they are paid to do.   Good luck! Bee - Good luck to you too on your "flip" surgery. Caligrlof68 - I have also heard of the fat transfers from other areas to "fill"in spaces.  I would like to know more about this but don't know where to look or ask.  Also, anyone else out there having issues with their underarm muscles?   Mine bother me so much still.   Thank goodness the pain has mostly subsided.   My muscles are lumpy feeling, stiff and sore still.   I have been going to a PT some.  I just wonder how long the muscles will be like this.
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2009 09:06PM hope4cure wrote: caligrlof68 - my PT gave me some really odd sounding remedies for softening up scar tissue.   I am going to have to ask about it when I go back this Thursday.   I am going to also go for a larger fill this time.  I think I only took 60 ccs when I went last time because the time before hurt.  This last time didn't so I think I will go for more.  my560sel - Yes, I am some better but still very tight.   I still have to watch what bras and shirts I wear.  If they are too tight under the arm, I just cannot tolerate them.    This one exercise the PT person showed me has really helped.  It is taking a rod like a shower rod or broom handle and holding it out in front of you a few inches with your arms straight.   Then you push it up and out to each side.   It really helps to stretch the muscle under your arm without putting a big strain on it.  Thought I would post this in case anyone else wanted to give it a try too. Jennifer
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2009 10:39PM hope4cure wrote: Hi all, It has been awhile since I posted.  The last fill went well and I am now up to 270ccs.  I am reading 2new1s and Suegmomof3 posts and you are both at 600ccs!   Wow!!  I must be a lot slower with my fills.   I guess I will get there eventually.  This last Thursday I had a fill.  This time we went with 90ccs.  It didn't bother me too much.  I was like WOWZA with the results.  I was C cup before and I think it is getting pretty close to that now.  I believe I want to go as far as I can.   So far, my skin is holding up.   We will see.   Bee and 2new1s - I was really happy to hear your good news!   Bee - that is so awesome to go in and then leave shortly afterward.   What a great day! Michele - Thank you so much for the encouragement regarding the implant.  I am looking forward to the final step!   It is great to hear that you have made it and feel so good.   Yeah! Take care everyone! Jennifer
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2009 10:35AM hope4cure wrote: Hi all, Dani - sounds like you are feeling a little better maybe?  I understand - it is hard to decide and you feel like it is so "final'.  I have an appointment Tuesday for my final consult before surgery - at least that is what I believe.   I will be thinking about you and hoping all goes well.  I am sure it will go well.  Hang in there!   It will be better to have it done and behind you!   That is what I keep saying to myself.   My DH says I have been pretty stressed out lately knowing it is coming up soon.  We are tough - we have made it this far - we can make it the rest of the way! Bee - glad you are doing well and past the surgery now.  Has to be a relief I am sure.  I hate drains too!   They were awful!  I have heard others say that the implants are much more comfortable.   Let me know what you find out about the tattoos.  That sounds like the way to go.  I got a chuckle from your last post.   It is sort of liberating to not have to worry about "showing through" a shirt.   Gotta look on the bright side.  jillisucat - glad you are doing well too. ~ Jennifer
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2009 08:31PM hope4cure wrote:
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2009 08:21PM hope4cure wrote: Hey there, I have read several posts where patients get a dye injection before surgery.   My doctor has said nothing about this injection.   I am suppose to have a bilateral mastectomy with TE on the 23rd.   They are suppose to take the sentinel node at the time.   Am I missing something here?  Jill - good luck to you and everyone else on this board!   Glad we have each other to talk to and share the hope and well wishes!
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2009 06:17PM hope4cure wrote: Sue - That is incredible!   Sounds like something that would happen to me.  At this point - I would go through just about anything to get these darn things out.   I don't blame you for not giving up!!!  I wouldn't have either!!   Tomorrow - OH how I am counting down the hours with anticipation.   They are coming out one way or another.   I asked my DH to bring home a philly cheesesteak pizza tonight.  Comfort food  - YUM He is not here yet and I here trying to get my mind off of it.      ~ Jennifer
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2009 09:29PM hope4cure wrote: TXBadboob -  Yes, I have shooting pains now and then too.   It also seems to be on the right side.   Very interesting.   Perhaps since that is possibly our most dominant arm could we be overdoing it and then paying for it later?   Not sure.   The right side was my bad side so I also wonder if they worked on that side more making it more sore.    I am still taking the stronger pain killers.   But, I am down to like 3 pills a day now.   I was taking the max dose when I first came home.   I am trying to wean myself off of them but haven't been able to as of yet.   2new1s - I have read your prior posts and I know you really have had a tough time.   You have been a trooper and quite upbeat for what you have gone through.  I think attitude really helps in the healing process.   Sharing your concerns on here does help too.  It is good your DH is supportive.   That is great.  My PS didn't offer the nipple sparing surgery.   According to her it was breast tissue that needed to go.   I plan to do tattoos later for the nipples.   Seems odd but they do look pretty real.    Maybe you can check into that too.  dani - I totally relate to doing a little and then being wiped out.   I am also very sensitive to fabric.   I am still using ABDs under my surgical bra.   I tried the sports bra the other day and after a couple hours I was done.   It made me hurt worse.  The PS prescribed a cream to put on the incision which I put on faithfully and then use the ABD pads over them and then put on the surgical bra.   It works for me and seems to make the incision heal pretty fast.   I am going to ask about this and other things when I go Tuesday.    I don't want to keep using ABDs,  they get costly after awhile.   my560sel - Sounds like you are feeling better.  I think we all go through a wide range of emotions throughout our BC journey.  It is normal.  Only people who have experienced the same or similiar issues can really relate and sympathize.   Sleep is good - it helps you heal better and cope with things.  Here is sending good healing thoughts your way.  Have a good night everyone.   Signing off and going to get some zzz's too.
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2009 02:11PM hope4cure wrote: That is so crazy - why are we told different things?    I asked about my range of motion and exercises and they didn't suggest any.   They said I would get my range of motion back in time.   They discouraged any exercises until I was done with the final swap.   I was told to take it easy and I would heal faster.  suegmomof3 - I wish my PS told me that they would send me to a PT if I needed it but I wouldn't have wanted to do any exercises with drains.  OUCH!   I was told to keep a bra on 24/7 because it would help the expanders stay in place, etc. etc.   They just said to stay away from underwire bras.  Bee - I live SE of Mt Vernon in the country.    So, are you close to Terre Haute?  I have been through there several times.  I love the Turkey Run State Park in Indiana and I love to take the road tour of all the covered bridges.    I have also been to Indianapolis several times since my husband is in the automotive field and goes up there for regular conferences/trainings to keep up with the latest technology.
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2009 08:31PM hope4cure wrote: Terri - great news on the drains!   I remember how awful they felt.   It is a relief to get them out. Bee - glad all is going well with you even though you didn't get the eyes done. I am not sure when I will get the exchange done.  I am beginning to think I will be the last of the February group to get it done.  I will let you know when I know. I hate to say I am not impressed with my PS and the more I go - well, the more I am dissatisfied.  I am hoping things work out and I will let you know more later.   ~ Jennifer
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2009 09:24PM hope4cure wrote: Hi all, I made it!!   The surgery went well - better than expected.   I am not experiencing the pain as with the first surgery.   In fact, I feel pretty good.   My husband and I even went out to eat tonight.   I am so relieved to have it done and behind me now.   They turned out pretty well.  I do have a wrinkle on one side which I do not like so much but I had this immediately after the first surgery and it has to do with the skin pocket they made for it orginally.  So, I am not sure what they will do with that.  Perhaps we can fill it in with some fat from somewhere else.  I don't know.  Has anyone else had that issue?   If so, what did they do for it? Thanks for all the well wishes!   I so appreciated them.  BTW:  I swapped out for 550cc implant.   I might have liked a little bigger but this is pretty close to my old size.   Does anyone know what a 550cc implant translates to in cup size?  ~ Jennifer
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2009 05:29AM hope4cure wrote: Hi all, Hope you are doing well.   Bee - let us know how you are doing.   Sorry to hear about your troubles.   Keep hanging in there!     Terri - the implants will be much more comfortable.  January will be here before you know it. 2new1s - how are the 2 new ones?  Are you feeling alright? My recon has gone well and will be doing the "final touches" before too long.   - Jennifer
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2009 01:05AM - edited Mar 17, 2009 01:10AM by hope4cure I also had a bilateral MX with TE on 2/23.  I still have a good amount of pain but it has improved slowly since the surgery.  The biggest improvement came after the drains came out.  They felt like hot knives in my sides.   Now that they are gone, I feel soreness and pressure instead of the stabbing pain.  I cannot sleep flat or semi-flat.  I have been only able to get to sleep in my recliner at an angle.  The expanders really hurt when I lie flat.  My sides also really hurt when I try to sit up from a flat position.   It is intense.  I had talked to my PS and they said everyone is different, but, what I am describing they have heard before.   I am also concerned this pain will remain until the TEs come out.   I can manage the pain but it NEVER goes away for me.   I have limited ability in reaching and (interestingly enough) one side hurts much worse than the other.   I certainly sympathize with you.   Keep the faith.   Hope your appointment goes well!
Posts.Title: bil/mas with t/e, when will I feel comfortable again? jpixstix JanMarch

Posts.Content: hope4cure wrote: I am so new to all of this and cannot sleep well.  I am 39 and was diagnosed with DCIS, Level 0 at the end of September.   I went through surgery (partial mastectomy.) on Oct 7, 2008 and was told the surgery was successful.   I am very grateful for that but now I fear I have something perhaps worse. I have been to 2 oncologists.   The latest one had me do a MRI since my breasts are very dense.   She called me this past Friday and said the MRI images were "suspicious" and scheduled me to see a surgeon this coming Friday.   I am pretty scared.  I have a 6 year old and want to see her grow up.  We also wanted to have more children.  I feel I am on this really terrible roller coaster ride and want to get off and no one is letting me off.  Just when I think I might be getting off - here I go again!    I find it so incredible that MRIs can show something a mammogram cannot.   I am hoping the result on the MRI is really nothing.   At this point, I believe I am ready for double mastectomy.  That way, I don't have to worry about this crazy stuff anymore. This is the first time I have every posted anything to a blog.  This all has been so difficult for me to talk about it but I feel the need to connect to people who are going through the same thing.   It is hard to find anyone who "really" understands.  Has anyone out there had a situation of 2 types of cancers?  Are MRI's really better than mammograms?   If so, shouldn't anyone with BC get it - just to be safe?   Should I be all worked up over this?    Friday is 4 days away but feels like an eternity. Dx 9/23/2008, DCIS, 1cm, Stage 0, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 2 Types of Cancer? - MRI better than Mammograms? hope4cure lisa-e

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2008 06:16AM hope4cure wrote: Hi, I am so new to all of this and cannot sleep well.  I am 39 and was diagnosed with DCIS, Level 0 at the end of September.   I went through surgery (partial mastectomy.) on Oct 7, 2008 and was told the surgery was successful.   I am very grateful for that but now I fear I have something perhaps worse. I have been to 2 oncologists.   The latest one had me do a MRI since my breasts are very dense.   She called me this past Friday and said the MRI images were "suspicious" and scheduled me to see a surgeon this coming Friday.   I am pretty scared.  I have a 6 year old and want to see her grow up.  We also wanted to have more children.  I feel I am on this really terrible roller coaster ride and want to get off and no one is letting me off.  Just when I think I might be getting off - here I go again!    I find it so incredible that MRIs can show something a mammogram cannot.   I am hoping the result on the MRI is really nothing.   At this point, I believe I am ready for double mastectomy.  That way, I don't have to worry about this crazy stuff anymore. This is the first time I have every posted anything to a blog.  This all has been so difficult for me to talk about it but I feel the need to connect to people who are going through the same thing.   It is hard to find anyone who "really" understands.
Posts.Title: MRI guided biopsy thebabylisa lilsunshine

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2009 07:05PM hope4cure wrote: Red91RU - I am doing very well with my fills.   I had another one on Tuesday and this time I didn't have much discomfort at all.  The first one I had soreness the next day but this time it was fine.  I only did 60 this time around.   The more you do the more you stretch and feel discomfort.   They gave me the option while I was there.   I am doing really well as far as getting back to my old self.   I was able to sleep in bed this week with the help of several pillows.  I was glad to have moved from the recliner.    I also went back to work this week.   It went well but I am tired.   I didn't have much energy and did have some difficulty concentrating.   I guess it will be better with time. Pam3467 - hopefully your pain will go away in the next few weeks.   The 5-6th week was the turning point for me with the pain.   Looking back on all the pain I experienced, I would have to say it felt like someone ran my chest over with a lawnmower.   That about sums it up.    Fortunately, it doesn't feel like that now.  Hope everyone has a great Easter weekend! Jennifer
Posts.Title: bil/mas with t/e, when will I feel comfortable again? jpixstix JanMarch

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2009 11:09PM hope4cure wrote: Karen  - So glad you got the drains out.  You will definitely see an improvement with how you feel now those are out.   I felt almost exactly the same way.   At first, it was great and then I was like really sore and tired for the next few days.   I think it is your body recovering from the drains.  It has to heal those places up.  Within 3 or 4 days after the drains were removed, I felt much better.   It was a good moment.   Then I ever so gradually felt better each day - that is as long as I didn't over do it by doing something that I should have left alone.   Watch out for pulling car doors shut.  That really hurts.   Another thing that bothered me was adjusting the shower head in my shower.  That was painful and I wouldn't recommend it.   Get someone else to do it.  You don't think of all those small things until you are faced with it and it is like UGH - I feel so helpless!    I am four weeks out now and feeling much much better.   The fill went great.   Not a problem.  The PS was very pleased on how my incision was healing.  I was totally jazzed.   The fill was interesting.  I did feel the needle a little on the right side but nothing on the left.   It was actually odd that I felt anything because generally you don't.    I do have some feeling back and maybe that is an odd thing.  I don't know.   The PS also told me that 3 months out from the surgery is generally a good time for most patients.   She said most say they really start to feel like their old selfs again.  I am looking forward to that.  About the pain meds - good thing they gave you some more.   I still use mine but just not as often.   I totally understand the expander pain.  I told a friend of mine it was like wearing the worst underwire bra ever and it is under your skin.   You want to adjust it but cannot.  I still sleep in the recliner because I cannot bear to sleep on my back.  It just hurts me too much.  The PS said everyone is different and some feel it worse than others.  She said I will eventually get where I want to be.   I can tolerate it but glad it is only temporary.   The expanders are nothing like the drains.  They were the killers. Take care! Jennifer
Posts.Title: bil/mas with t/e, when will I feel comfortable again? jpixstix JanMarch

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2009 11:20AM hope4cure wrote: Hi all, It has been a little while since I have posted.   I am exactly at 6 weeks from my surgery date today and feel much better.   Last week was a turning point for me, I started to feel more "alive" again.   Pain is still there to some degree but nothing like it was before.  It is pretty mild now and I have gradually weaned myself off the narcotics.  I am just taking Aleve once in awhile.  I start back to work today but I telecommute out of my house so I don't have to drive anywhere.   That is great.  Driving makes me tired and sore.   I was able to actually lie in bed and sleep this week.  I haven't made it all night without having to get up and move back to the recliner, but this is much more than I could do before.   I have another fill tomorrow.   Hope that goes well. Bigapple - I am no expert here but I am guessing your pain has to do with muscles and tendons.  Hopefully, your BS will give you some help with it.   I would watch out for extra redness and swelling though.
Posts.Title: bil/mas with t/e, when will I feel comfortable again? jpixstix JanMarch

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2009 10:52PM hope4cure wrote: SYGI -  I chose both at the time because I wanted to get it all over with at one time, get the final path report and move on with my life.   I also wanted to be sure they both matched up well and with doing both at the same time, I was told it was much easier for the surgeons to do so.  Lastly, from what I know now about the pain, I probably would have been too chicken to go back and do the other side if I had only done one.   Some people have a lot of pain and others do not.  I did have a lot of pain and I just don't know if I would have had the courage to go through it a 2nd time.    It was best for me to do it all at one time and get through it.   Now that I am 6 weeks post op, I am feeling much better.    Furthermore, it will save you on countless more doctor visits, driving etc.   It is totally up to you.   This is just my experience.   Good luck!   I know the decision is a very difficult one to make.
Posts.Title: bil/mas with t/e, when will I feel comfortable again? jpixstix JanMarch

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2009 12:54AM hope4cure wrote: Red It really irritated me to hear your doctor lectured you on the pain meds.  I am like 4 weeks out now and still use the "strong" stuff whenever I feel like it.   I don't overuse it but I do use it when I have enough pain to warrant it.   I could not have managed the pain at all if I didn't have pain meds while I still had the drains.   The drains were the killers for me.   I had a total of 4 which I did get rid of by the 2nd week.   I was totally happy to get rid of them.  The pain was really bad while I still had them.   Please take care of yourself right now.  It sounds like you might be overdoing it a little.  That might set you back if you are not careful.   Also, I would take the pain meds if I felt like it.   It is important to not be in a lot of pain - this can also slow down your recovery.  URG to that doctor!   They should walk in your shoes awhile! Also, to all the other people with sore armpits.  I can also relate.  It hurts very bad under and around the armpits.  I have "rolls" of skin under my arms which seem hard as rocks.  I am thinking it is a combination of extra skin after the surgery and muscles who have been moved around because of the TEs.   The worst pain first came from the drains.  After they were gone, the pain is now more under the armpit.   I am going for my first fill on Tuesday.  I am going to ask questions about the armpits, muscles, pain and other things when I go.  Hope you all feel better soon.  I know the drains are terrible.   Once they are out - you will feel relief.   Also, the drains coming out did not hurt much at all - it was just an ICKY feeling.  I was actually really looking forward to getting them out since that was what was hurting the most.   Also, you will feel better little by little, day by day.  I feel way better now (4 weeks post op) than I did right after the surgery.   Hang in there!   Jennifer
Posts.Title: bil/mas with t/e, when will I feel comfortable again? jpixstix JanMarch

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2009 01:30AM hope4cure wrote: Red - Thanks for asking.  I am feeling some better.  I thought about returning to work today but didn't have it in me.  I get so tired so easily.   It really doesn't take much at all.  I still sleep in the recliner but I want to be comfortable and get the needed sleep.    I have been off work 5 weeks now.  I do have to go back next week but I think I will do light duty for awhile.  I hope your appt went well with your PS today.   Just my opinion, I think the swelling is pretty normal.  I think your body will be swollen for awhile.   The drains helped to keep down the swelling but I don't miss them at all.   Your body can really absorb more than you think it can. Indomitable1 -  Typically PS suggest taking 4-6 weeks off work after surgery.  Some people can do that and some cannot.   I am glad I have taken off the time.  I thought about returning this week but I haven't felt good enough as of yet.  cs34-  my heart goes out to you.  I would be really frustrated if I had to wear the drain 4 weeks out.  YIKES!   I thought 2 weeks was too much!   Keep thinking positive though!   If you don't think positive, it will seem even longer.   You will get there - just hang on! Bigapple09 - I have no idea what 410 implants stand for?   What kind are they?
Posts.Title: bil/mas with t/e, when will I feel comfortable again? jpixstix JanMarch
